um a few empirical discoveries that will
that people will continue to find uh

will be the most uh exhaustive stud stud
of one aspect of child language

errors like uh I uh we holded the baby
rabbits or the alligator go klunk where

stick producing errors like sticked and
teared and holded uh I analyzed 20,000
of those forms uh from computer

language and uh developed a theory
of why kids make that error uh how they
outgrow it and what it shows about
language the
reason to obsess over a tiny little
topic like that is that it's a nice
illustration of children's creativity in
acquiring language the the essence of
language is that you aren't restricted
to a fixed list of messages that you've
memorized and that you then regurgitate
like a parrot rather you you recreate
recombine elements to create new
messages every sentence that we utter is
a brand new sentence but it's rather
hard to study the process of of kids
making up new sentences when a kid says
something like sticked or teared or
heared or holded that's a tiny example
of recombination that I think is the
engine that powers language as a whole
the uh the the act of children making an
error like that I think is a way of
catching them in the act of doing
something that makes language powerful
namely combining things by rules and in
trying to understand that one phenomenon
I hope that we my students and I uh shed

Crack the Code of what verbs mean and

um that I I I cracked a lot of that code
uh what's the difference between a verb

a verb meaning are

tractable it's something that you can uh
single person can hope to make Headway
on uh in in a

that the reason that we have language is

that language is an evolutionary

uh technological knowhow by allowing us

kind of a nutshell description of how

uh and I like to think I've done the
